p.seg: The mind is the basis for manifestationlg==
the mind is noble, the mind disposes.lg==
If in one's mind one thinks bad thoughtslg==
and thus speaks, and thus acts,lg==
then the bitter results of this misdeed will naturally pursue onelg==
in the manner of carts passing through their rut.lg==
The mind is the basis for manifestationlg==
the mind is noble, the mind disposes.lg==
If in one'smind one thinks good thoughtslg==
and then speaks accordingely, and then acts accordingly,lg==
then good fortune and joy will naturally pursue one,lg==
like a shadow following a shape.lg==
If one acts following confused thoughtlg==
one is constricted to stupidity and enters darkness;lg==
when one is self-aggrandising, without the Buddhist Way,lg==
how can one unravel and understand good words?lg==
If one acts following proper thoughtslg==
then one will open up, will be enlightened;lg==
one will not act on envy,lg==
and nimbly one will understand properly good words.lg==
He who bears a grudge against the resentment of others,lg==
will never be without such resentment by others;lg==
not to bear a grudge, to naturally cut oneself off from it,lg==
this way may be taken as the ultimately important truth.lg==
Do not indulge in blaming others,lg==
make it your business to reflect on your own person;lg==
if you have understood how to do thislg==
you will be extinguished (into Nirvana) and be without troubles.lg==
In your action show that your person is pure.lg==
If you do not restrain your senseslg==
if in drinking and eating you are not moderate,lg==
if you are lazy and chicken-livered-weak,lg==
if you are controlled by wickedness of mind,lg==
then you are like the grass bent by the wind.lg==
If you observe the impurities of your personlg==
and you can restrain your senses,lg==
if in eating you know how to be moderatelg==
and you always enjoy making spiritual progress,lg==
if you are not moved by motives of wickedness,lg==
then you are like a large mountain (standing firm) in the wind.lg==
One who does not vomit the poisons within,lg==
Whose craving mind races about,lg==
Who has not tamed himself;lg==
should not dress the Buddhist way.lg==
One who is able to vomit the poisons within,lg==
who can admonish/constrain his mind and remain tranquil,lg==
who subdues the mind and has controlled it,lg==
this person should dress the Buddhist way.lg==
If you take the genuine/true to be fake,lg==
if you take the fake to be true,lg==
this is an evil strategy,lg==
and you will not gain the profit that comes from what is genuine and true.lg==
If you understand what is genuine/true and practise what is true,lg==
if when you see the fake you understand that it is fake,lg==
then this is the right strategylg==
and you are sure to gain the benefit that comes from what is genuine/true.lg==
Surely, when a roof is not water-tightlg==
then when it is raining, it will leak;lg==
when one's thinking is not mindful of one's actionslg==
then lust will find its way into (one's mind)lg==
Surely, when the roof is nicely watertightlg==
when it is raining then it won't leak;lg==
when you constrain your thoughts and you are mindful of your actions,lg==
then indulgence will not arise.lg==
When a vulgar person influences someone elselg==
this is like (that person) getting close to a stinking object;lg==
he will get increasingly confused and will get used to doing the wrong things,lg==
he will fail to become enlightened and will become wicked.lg==
When a person of moral worth influences another personlg==
it is as if (that person) gets close to a perfume;lg==
he will enter wisdom and practise goodnesslg==
and his actions will bring about a pure fragrance.lg==
If one creates troubles, then afterwards one will have troubles,lg==
if one does evil then the two parties (the doer and the one who suffers the injustice) will have troubles;lg==
that person who has troubles will think fearful thoughtslg==
and seeing the crimes (he commits) his mind will be full of fear.lg==
When one creates joy one will afterwards be joyful,lg==
and when one does good then both parties will be pleased;lg==
when that other person is joyful one will only think of this pleasurelg==
seeing the good fortune one's mind will be at ease.lg==
If now you have (reason for) regret, then later you will have (reason for) regret.lg==
If you do evil, then both parties (you, the offender and the person you offend against) have (reason for) regret:lg==
your action lead to your own misfortune,lg==
and the person who received the injustice will suffer anxieties.lg==
If now you are pleased you will be pleased later,lg==
and if you do good both parties (the agent as well as the recipient) will be pleased,lg==
your acting will be of spiritual aid to yourselflg==
you will receive good fortune, and you will be full of delight.lg==
If you polish your rhetoric and are full of cravings,lg==
if you are profligate and uncontrolled,lg==
if you harbour indecent desires, anger and foolishness,lg==
if you are not mindful of what arrests your regard,lg==
if you join the common crowd as in a herd of cows,lg==
then you are not a disciple of the Buddha.lg==
If you speak at the proper times, and if you seek few things,lg==
if you practise the Way in accordance with the Law,lg==
if you remove all indulgence, anger, and foolishness,lg==
if you wake up to what is correct and unravel/understand it in your thinking,lg==
then, as such, you are a disciple of the Buddha.lg==

div.head:
放逸品《法句經》第十有二十章
[The purpose of] this chapter on "Heedfulness" [Wantonness CH]

p.seg: The ethical life is the Way to immortality;lg==
Heedlessness is the Path to deathlg==
Those without craving never die;lg==
To lose the Way is to lose one's life. (1)lg==
The wise excels in guarding the Way (2)lg==
And never becomes heedless.lg==
Not craving, one attains to happiness;lg==
From whence the bliss of attainment (3) is obtained (4).lg==
One should constantly devote to meditation,lg==
Be firm, and persevere in the proper course.lg==
The strong ones can [thus] transcend existence,lg==
And [attain Nirvana], the Supremely Auspicious (5). [There is no auspiciousness greater than that. CH]]lg==
One who always gives rise to right mindfulness,lg==
And whose actions are pure; his evil will easily eradicated,lg==
Self-restrained, living by Dharma,lg==
not transgressing (6) he earns a good name that spread afar (7).lg==
Bringing forth effort and being heedful, .lg==
Restraining himself and taming his mind,lg==
The wise makes an illuminator (8) [for himself],lg==
And does not return to the sea of darkness (9)lg==
It is difficult to understand the fools' mind;lg==
It is greedy, scattered and delights in disputeslg==
The intelligent man values caution,lg==
And protects it as his precious wealth (10).lg==
Do not crave or delight in disputes, .lg==
And do not indulge in sensual pleasure.lg==
He who practises meditation and heedfulness,lg==
Can gain great happiness (11)lg==
To be heedless is like to be self-imprisoned. [inhibiting oneself CH]lg==
He who realizes this is a noble one. [get rid of this uncontrolled extravagance CH]lg==
Who has ascended to wisdom's mansion,lg==
Free from danger, truly safe.lg==
Such a wise man looks down upon the foolish,lg==
Like [one] on the mountain and [the other] on the ground.lg==
Upright amindst the chaotic, remains upright,lg==
One is uniquely awakened.lg==
Such a man's power surpasses a lion's.lg==
Abandoning evil, he becomes the Greatly Wise (13).lg==
By drowsiness, heavy as a mountainlg==
The deluded one is covered (14).lg==
Lying down comfortably, he ackowledges no suffering,lg==
And hence enters the womb again and again (15).lg==
There can be no occasion for self-indulgence; [If one does not practise constant self-indulgence... CH???]lg==
He who is well-restrained can exhaust the cankers.lg==
The moment when one indulges, Mara gets his chance,lg==
Like a lion (waiting) to catch the deer (16).lg==
He who has no self-indulgence,lg==
Is a disciplined bhiksu.lg==
He, whose thoughts are well calmedlg==
Should constantly guard mind (17).lg==
A bhiksu finds happiness (18) in caution;lg==
Heedlessness gives him much worries.lg==
Changing disputes from small to big,lg==
And accumulating evil, he gets himself into fire (10).lg==
The precept observance is meritious and brings happiness;lg==
Transgressing the precepts produces fear at heart.lg==
Destroying the cankers of the three spheres.lg==
One comes close to Nirvana (20).lg==
If one was heedless earlier,lg==
But regains self-control laterlg==
- Such a one illumines the world.lg==
Being mindful, he is focussed on proper [actions] (21)lg==
If one made mistakes in doing evil,lg==
But later covers over it by doing goodlg==
-Such a one illumines the world.lg==
Being mindful, he becomes skillful in proper [actions] (22)lg==
If one abandons the homelife when young and strong .lg==
To vigourously practise the Buddha's teachinglg==
-Such a one illumines the world,lg==
Like the moon freed from clouds (23)lg==
If one previously had committed evillg==
But later stops and commits no more;lg==
-Such a one illumes the world,lg==
Like the moon freed from clouds.lg==
He who when living does naught to cause suffering,lg==
And at death does not grieve;lg==
Has seen the Truth (25), and is fearless.lg==
He feels no sorrow where [others] do (26).lg==
He who can illiminate the black dharmas,lg==
And trains only in the pure white ones;lg==
Will cross over the deep water, never to return.lg==
He moves about with no attachment (27),lg==
Unsullied by [sensual] pleasure,lg==
With no craving, and no sorrow (28).lg==

div.head:
心意品《法句經》第十一十有二章
心意品者， The chapter on 'Mind'

p.seg: Mind rushes to echoes, (1) (read: 駛作響 with Ming and Qing editions)lg==
It is difficult to guard, to restrain.lg==
The wise straightens its base, (2)lg==
And its brightness then becomes great. (3)lg==
[Mind] is fickle, hard to take care of (5) Fickleness is hard to keep firm control of CH)lg==
It complies with every desire.lg==
To subdue the mind is excellentlg==
One's mind tamed, there will be calm. (6)lg==
Mind is subtle, difficult to discern;lg==
It moves according with craving.lg==
The wise always protects his own mind;lg==
When it is guarded, there will be peace (7)lg==
[Mind] travels alone, going far off,lg==
Is concealed and incorporeal;lg==
Those who restrain (8) this mind, drawing near the Waylg==
Will be released from Mara's bonds. (10)lg==
If the mind does not settle down,lg==
Or know the Dharma;lg==
And is deluded in worldly affairs;lg==
There will be no proper understanding (11)lg==
Thoughts do not stop where they should;lg==
They are ceaseless and endless. (12)lg==
Meritorious actions can halt evil,lg==
He who is aware [of this] is noble. (13)lg==
Though the mental events taught by Buddha,lg==
Are subtle and not [ultimately] real;lg==
One must beware of the indulgent thoughts,lg==
And not let mind go as it likes. (14)lg==
Seeing the Dharma, one is happiest.lg==
One's aims will be fulfilled.lg==
The wise guards the subtle thoughts,lg==
And break the causal conditions for suffering. (15)lg==
The body cannot be had for long,lg==
It will return completely to the ground;lg==
Body decayed and consciousness departed -lg==
What can one covet as a boarder therein? (16) (Since one lives in one's body for a limited time...CH)lg==
The mind strives to (17) build dwelling places,lg==
To come and go endlessly.lg==
[If] one's thoughts are mostly devious,lg==
One incurs troubles (18) for oneself. (19)lg==
It is one's own mind which causes [suffering]lg==
Not one's father or mother.lg==
One must then work hard to align with the right,lg==
And not turn back from meritorious actions. (20)lg==
Conceal the six [senses] like a tortoise. (21)lg==
Guard the mind like [the army guarding] the capital, (guard against wild thoughts like a city wall CH)lg==
Fight Mara with wisdom; (The wise fights Mara CH)lg==
And if victorious, there will be no more trouble. (22)lg==

div.head:
華香品《法句經》第十二十有七章
華香品者， The chapter on 'Flower Fragrance'

p.seg: Who can select (1) the land (2).lg==
Leaving hells(read 監"prison>hell(???)) (3) behind and preferring heavens?lg==
Who [can] speak the words of Dharma (4),lg==
Like picking (1) the good flowers (5)?lg==
A trainee can select the land,lg==
Leaving hells behind and preferring heavens.lg==
He speaks well the Words of Dharmalg==
And can pick flowers of virtues (7).lg==
He who knows worldly phenomena as earthenware,lg==
Illusory, and coming abruptly into excistence;lg==
Will break the blooming of Mara's flowers (8),lg==
And see no more of the lord of death (10).lg==
He who sees the body to be foam,lg==
And all phenomena to be illusory by naturelg==
Will break the blooming of Mara's flowers,lg==
And see no more of the lord of death (10).lg==
When the body is sick, it withers away,lg==
Like the wilting flowers.lg==
When death befalls one,lg==
It dashes like rapids (11).lg==
He who is insatiate in desires,lg==
His mind becomes distracted.lg==
Amassing wealth through evil means,lg==
He makes an attack on himself (12).lg==
As a bee gathers [honey from] flowers,lg==
Without disturbing their colour and fragrance,lg==
Taking away only their tastelg==
likewise do the sages (13) enter the village (14)lg==
Do not seek to observe otherslg==
As to what they have or have not done;lg==
Always make self-reflexionlg==
To know one's rights and wrongs (15)lg==
As a flower pleasing to the mind,lg==
With good colour but no fragrance;lg==
Likewise are fine (16) wordslg==
Which if not practised yield no gain (17).lg==
As a flower pleasing to the mind,lg==
With beautiful colour as well as fragrance;lg==
Likewise are fine (18) wordslg==
Which if practised yield blessings (18).lg==
If one gathers (19) many precious flowers,lg==
The garlands (20) made will be of distinguished beauty,lg==
[Likewise] if one accumulates much virtues,lg==
One's station of birth will change for the better (22).lg==
Distinguished (23) plants and scented flowers,lg==
Do not perfume against the wind;lg==
Those close to the blooming of Enlightenment (24).lg==
- The virtuous - diffuse frangrance in all directions (25)lg==
Sandal wood and various scented substances (16)lg==
Blue lotus, fragrant flowerslg==
- [Their fragrance] though said to be real,lg==
Is inferior to the fragrance of morality (27).lg==
The fragrance of flowers is faint;lg==
It cannot be called real.lg==
The fragrance of ethical alignmentlg==
Reaches up to the heavens- It is excellent (28)lg==
Those who are perfect in morality,lg==
Whose actions are not heedless,lg==
And who are freed through a concentrated mind (29)lg==
Is far apart from Mara's path (30).lg==
As in a field-ditch (31)lg==
Near the main road,lg==
A lotus could bloom,lg==
Fragrant, clean and charming (32).lg==
Likewise, in the cycle of rebirth (33)lg==
Amidst the [lowest] end of worldlings (34),lg==
The wise ones delight in going forth (35),lg==
To be disciples of the Buddha (36).lg==

div.head:
愚闇品《法句經》第十三二十有一章
愚闇品者， The aim of this chapter on 'The Fool'

p.seg: For the wakeful the night is long.lg==
For the weary, a journey is long.lg==
For the fools, the cycle of rebirths is long,lg==
Not knowing the True Dharma (1).lg==
The fool's deluded mind is always in darkness,lg==
Flowing on like a river.lg==
It's better to fare on singly [than go with fools],lg==
Alone with no companions (2).lg==
Falling into the company of fools (3)lg==
leads to sorrow for long.lg==
Living with fools is painful,lg==
Like being at enmity with oneself (4)lg==
"I have sons, I have wealth"lg==
So thinking, the fool is perturbed.lg==
When even the self is not of one's own,lg==
Whence (5) sons and wealth? (6)lg==
"In summer I shall stay here;lg==
In winter I shall stay here" (7)lg==
Thus is the fool always apprehensive,lg==
Not knowing the changes in the future (8).lg==
The fool, ignorant of his extreme folly,lg==
Claims himself to be wise.lg==
Being foolish and yet [claiming] to excel (8) the wiselg==
-This is foolishness to the extreme (10).lg==
A fool's association with the wiselg==
Is like a ladle [being unable] to taste,lg==
Though he has taken liberties with (11) [the wise] for long,lg==
He still remains ignorant of the Dharma (12).lg==
An intelligent man's assocciation with the wiselg==
Is like the tongue tasting the flavour;lg==
Even if he just learns for a moment,lg==
He understands at once the essence of the Way (13).lg==
A fool performs actionslg==
To incur troubles for himself.lg==
With a happy mind he does evil,lg==
Causing great sorrow [in future] (14).lg==
The kind of action is not good,lg==
Which receding from it one will regret;lg==
With tears in the facelg==
[To receive] the fruit from one's past practice (15).lg==
The kind of action is virtous and good,lg==
Which one will review happily;lg==
Being sure to receive good results,lg==
One is smilingly pleased with the practice (16).lg==
So long as a past evil has not ripened, (no past!CH)lg==
The fool is calm and at ease.lg==
When the time (17) comes for it to ripen,lg==
He will experience much affliction (18).lg==
The fool, looking from where he is,lg==
Sees not that he's heading towards suffering.lg==
When he is about to fall into adversity,lg==
He'll then realize that it's not good (19).lg==
When a foold does evil,lg==
He realizes not [its consequence].lg==
Troubles chase after him and he will burn himselflg==
- By his own evil, he is set ablaze (20)lg==
The fool covets good food'lg==
Month after month his nourishment increases.lg==
Yet he is not even worth one-sixteenth.lg==
Of one who has comprehended the Dharma (21).lg==
The mental preoccupation of a foollg==
Will never yield any benefit.lg==
He is [only] incurring punishment for himself; (22)lg==
And retribution [is certain] - it has a seal (23).lg==
One recognizes a fool by observing his situation:lg==
He gives not but seeks much;lg==
Where he falls into, there is no virtue or wisdom,lg==
But very often, evil deeds (24).lg==
Those away from the Way and close to craving,lg==
Are [ordained] for food and for a name as a trainee.lg==
As they are greedy and cling to the household,lg==
They abundantly take offerings [from] other clans (25).lg==
Don't aspire ambivalently as a trainee:lg==
Don't be a householder-renunciatelg==
Coveting the household goes against the Holy Teaching;lg==
And by so doing one will make oneself destitute (26).lg==
To do so is to be on a par with fools,lg==
And it only increases one's craving and conceitlg==
-The aspiration for gain is one thing;lg==
The wish for Nirvana (27) is another (28).lg==
Therefore, the knowledgeable oneslg==
Should go forth to be the Buddha's disciples.lg==
Leaving behind lust and worldly practices,lg==
He'll never get trapped in the cycle of rebirth (29).lg==

div.head:
明哲品《法句經》第十四
The chapter on 'The Wise'

p.seg: He who deeply examines good and evil,lg==
Knows at heart what to fear and shun.lg==
[Thus] fearing, he does not transgress,lg==
And there will always be happiness (1) and no sorrow.lg==
He who has merit from his previous life,lg==
Should mindfully continue his [good] practices.lg==
Goodness brings realization to his wishes,lg==
And his good fortune will increase (3).lg==
Believe in goodness and make merit.lg==
Be not tired of accumulation [good] practices.lg==
Believe and know that there is effect of good deed.lg==
Eventually, [all] will be clear.lg==
Always avoid unprofitable (5) [company].lg==
Do not be close to the fools.lg==
Think of following the good friends.lg==
Associate with the noble ones (6).lg==
He who finds joy (7) in Dharma sleeps well,lg==
With a happy an clear mind.lg==
The Dharma expounded by the Noble,lg==
The wise always delights in practising (8).lg==
The virtuous and wise ones,lg==
Observe precepts and follow the Way;lg==
Like the moon amidst stars,lg==
They illumine the world(9).lg==
Fletchers shape (10) the horns,lg==
Navigators shape their boats.lg==
Carpenters shape the wood,lg==
The wise ones shape themselves (11).lg==
Just as a thick rocklg==
Is unmoved by wind;lg==
The mind of the wise is heavy enoughlg==
Not to be upset by praise or blame (12).lg==
Just as a deep pondlg==
Is limped and clear;lg==
The wise, having heard the Dharmalg==
Becomes clear in his mind and happy (13).lg==
The great man has in his nature no craving,lg==
Every where he shines forth brightly.lg==
Though encoutering now pleasure now pain,lg==
He does not loftily show off his wisdom (14)lg==
The virtous one has no worldly engeagement;lg==
He desires neither sons nor wealth nor land.lg==
Always morallay conscious, wise and righteous (15),lg==
He covets not material success by unjust means (16).lg==
The wise one knows that when one wobbles,lg==
It is like a tree planted in sand.lg==
If amidst friends, one's mind is not yet firm,lg==
One gets tainted in accordance with their colours (17).lg==
The world is immersed in the sea;lg==
Few can cross over to the [other] shore.lg==
If there is anyonelg==
Wishing to cross, he must run fast (18).lg==
Those who sencerely desire the Truth (19)lg==
Accept the True Teachinglg==
- This is being near the Other Shore;lg==
It is best to be liberate from death (20).lg==
He who cuts off the five aggregates (21),lg==
Contemplative and wise,lg==
Does not return to the deep sea.lg==
Abandoning clinging (22) - this is being wise (23).lg==
He who controls his passions,lg==
Giving up pleasure, and craving for naught (24),lg==
Can cone to rescue himselflg==
From his sullied (25) mind - this is being wise (26).lg==
Those who train to obtain right knowledge,lg==
Who contemplate on true Enlightenment (27),lg==
Who accept Thruth with one mind,lg==
Who delight in not grasping (28),lg==
Whose cankers and conditionings are detroyedlg==
-Such persons have transcended the world (29).lg==

div.head:
羅漢品《法句經》第十五有十章
The chapter on 'The Arahat'

p.seg: Those whose mind is pure and are mindful,lg==
Delighting in nowhere;lg==
Have crossed the sea of delusion,lg==
Like swans who have abandoned their lake (4).lg==
Those who eat according to the stomach's capacity,lg==
Who accumulate nothing,lg==
Whose mind is empty and markless (5);lg==
Have passed the various stages of progresslg==
Like the birds in the skylg==
Which can go far unhindered (6).lg==
Those who have exhausted the world's conditioning (7)lg==
Who are no more hung up with food;lg==
Whose mind is empty and sorrow-free (8),lg==
Have reached the state of emancipation.lg==
They are [unattached] like flying birdslg==
Which land temporarily only to fly away (9).lg==
He whose senses are controlled, according with calm (10)lg==
Like horses well tamed,lg==
Who has abandoned conceit and the conditioning (11);lg==
Is respected by the gods (12).lg==
Without resentment, like the earth;lg==
Immovable, like a mountain;lg==
The true men are taintless,lg==
And have ended the worldly cycle of rebirths (13).lg==
His mind is already at rest,lg==
His words and deed too are tranquil (14).lg==
By right understanding he is freed;lg==
Calmly, he goes into appreasement (15).lg==
He who has given up craving and is detachedlg==
Who has broken the hindrances of the three spheres,lg==
And whose desires are annihilatedlg==
- Is indeed a superior man (16).lg==
Be it in village or in forest,lg==
Or on the plains or high lands.lg==
- Wherever the arahats (17) pass bylg==
It cannot but become blessed (18).lg==
He finds delight in the wilderness (19)lg==
Which the worldlings do not;lg==
Happy indeed are the unattachedlg==
Who seek no sensual pleasure (20).lg==

div.head:
述千品《法句經》第十六十有六章
The chapter on 'The thousands'

p.seg: Though one might recite thousand words (1);lg==
If their meanings be improper,lg==
It's better to recite one with essential [meaning]lg==
Hearing which thoughts will come to cease (2).lg==
Though one might recite a thousand chapters,lg==
What's the use if they be meaningless?lg==
It's better to recite one with meaning,lg==
Hearing and practising which one crosses over (4).lg==
Though one might recite many sutras,lg==
What's the use if one does not understand?lg==
[It's better] to understand one dharma verse (5),lg==
Practising which one may attain Enlightenment (6).lg==
Battling with thousands and thousands of men,lg==
One man might be the victor,lg==
But he who conquers himself is betterlg==
He is indeed the greatest in the battle (7).lg==
Best indeed is one who has conquered himselflg==
He is as such called the King of menlg==
Guarding his thoughts and training his self,lg==
He restrains himself till the end (8).lg==
Even the gods, said to be exalted,lg==
Or demigods or Mara or Brahma or Sakya,lg==
None of them can defeatlg==
A man who has conquered himself (9).lg==
One might each month offer sacrifices by the thousand,lg==
And continue doing so for one's whole life;lg==
This is not as good as, for a single momentlg==
Recollecting the Dharma with one-mindednesslg==
The merit produced by one such thoughtlg==
Excels that of [offering sacrifice] for a whole life (10).lg==
Though for a whole century,lg==
one might attend to the sacrificial fire;lg==
It's better, even if for a single moment,lg==
To make offerings to the Three Honoured Oneslg==
The merit of one such offeringlg==
Excels that of a century-long [sacrificial act] (11).lg==
If one offers sacrifice to gods, for the merit's sake,lg==
And subsequently espects reward from it;lg==
This would not amount to a fourth [the merit]lg==
From paying respect to the virtuous ones (12).lg==
In him who properly conforms to etiquettelg==
And always respects the elders.lg==
Four blessings automatically increase;lg==
Beauty, strength, long-life and happiness (13).lg==
If one lives a hundred years,lg==
Away from [mental] rectitude and unethical;lg==
It's better to live a single daylg==
Being ethical, mentally rectified and meditative (14).lg==
If one lives a hundred yearslg==
Crooked, insincere and without wisdom;lg==
It's better to live a single daylg==
With a concentrated mind and acquiring true wisdom (15).lg==
If one lives a hundred yearslg==
Sluggishly and without diligence;lg==
It's better to live a single day,lg==
Doing one's best and with diligence (16).lg==
If one lives a hundred yearslg==
Without perceiving the rise and fall of things;lg==
It's better to live a single day,lg==
Perceiving [that] subtlety and knowing what to shun (17).lg==
If one lives a hundred yearslg==
Without seeing the Path (18) of Ambrosia;lg==
It's better to live a single daylg==
Tasting-practising-the flavour of Ambrosia (19).lg==
If one lives a hundred yearslg==
Without knowing the great Righteousness (20).lg==
It's better to live a single daylg==
Studying the essentials of the Budddha's dharma (21).lg==

div.head:
惡行品《法句經》第十七二十有二章
The chapter on 'Evil Deeds'

p.seg: He who does not follow suit on seeing good done,lg==
Will reverse to follow his evil mind,lg==
He who does not seek to make merit properlylg==
Will reverse to delight in sexual misconduct (9).lg==
The ordinary worldlings, when doing evil,lg==
Are not aware themselves of [the danger involved] (2).lg==
Being foolish, they find pleasure in it,lg==
And thereby accumulate poison for the future (3).lg==
When a bad man does vices,lg==
He gets submerged in them again and again,lg==
Doing them with joyful desires.lg==
He receives accordingly the retribution of his evil (4).lg==
When a good man does virtuous deedslg==
[His virtues] increase progressively.lg==
Doing them with a willing mind,lg==
He receives accordingly the retribution of his merit (3).lg==
[Though] the evil man might see as meritlg==
His evil, while it has not ripened;lg==
When his evil ripens,lg==
He will experience the result of his evil (6).lg==
[Though] the virtous man might see as evillg==
His good deed, while it has not ripened;lg==
When his good deed ripenslg==
He will experience the blessing (7).lg==
He who strikes others will be struck.lg==
He who hates others will be hated.lg==
He who abuses others will be abused.lg==
He who is angry with others will get anger (8).lg==
The worldlings have no learning,lg==
And do not understand the True Dharma.lg==
Our life here is short;lg==
How is it proper to do evil (9)?lg==
Do not regard a tiny evil lightly,lg==
Thinking that it will bring no troubles.lg==
Water drops, though very tiny,lg==
Gradually fill up a big vessel:lg==
An evil is filled up,lg==
Bit by bit, to its accomplishment (10).lg==
Do not regard a tiny good lightly,lg==
Thinking that it will bring no meritlg==
Water drops, though very tinylg==
Gradually fill up a big vessel:lg==
A merit is filled up,lg==
By accumulating from the very tiniest.lg==
When a man performs an actionlg==
Wether it be a good or evil one,lg==
It is in each case for himself,lg==
And [its effect] is not obliterated at death (12).lg==
He who is fond of taking [others'things]lg==
May think that there's nothing wrong with it;lg==
[But] if you take things belonging to otherslg==
Others will also take your things (13).lg==
Evil done does not immediately [bear fruits];lg==
As in milking (14) a cow,lg==
Its retribution awaits in the nether world,lg==
As a fire concealed beneath ashes (15).lg==
One may laugh in doing an evil;lg==
[But] having (16) done it personally,lg==
One will cry in experiencing its retribution,lg==
When following one's action, the result of evil comes (17).lg==
Doing evil, [the fool] does not rise up (18),lg==
As if he has been blocked by an army.lg==
On being dragged along, he then realizes,lg==
That he has fallen into evil practice (19).lg==
He subsequently suffers the result,lg==
Of what he has done earlier (20).lg==
Like poison being rubbed into a woundlg==
Like a ship getting into an eddy,lg==
When evil deeds multiplylg==
They do harm to all (21).lg==
He who falsely accuses onelg==
Who is pure and unsulliedlg==
Harm will bounce back to this fool,lg==
Like dust thrown against the wind (22).lg==
Committing a mistake is not [necessarily] evil (23).lg==
It becomes good when one repents subsequently.lg==
Such a person illuminates the world,lg==
Like the unclouded sun (24).lg==
Wharever act a man has done (25),lg==
He will himself witness [the result]:lg==
A good act yields good [result].lg==
A evil act yields bad [result] (26).lg==
The consciousness of some (27) enter the womb:lg==
The Evil ones are born in hells;lg==
The doers of good (28) ascend to heavens.lg==
Those unattached to existence attain nirvana (29)lg==
Neither in the sky, nor mid-ocean,lg==
Nor hiding places in the mountains and rockslg==
No place is to be found herelg==
To escape the misfortune resulting from evil deed (30).lg==
All beings are [similarly] afflicted:lg==
Not being able to escape old age and death.lg==
Only the kind and wise [are spared],lg==
Not being bent on wrong and evil like others (31).lg==

div.head:
刀杖品《法句經》第十八十有四章
The chapter on 'Knives And Rods'

p.seg: All are afraid of death.lg==
None does not fear the pain [inflicted with] rods (2).lg==
Just as you would forgive yourself,lg==
Don't kill; don't strike with rods (3).lg==
He who ever cares for the well-being of creatures,lg==
And does not inflict pain on them;lg==
Will meet with no harm in this life,lg==
And be always well happy hereafter (4).lg==
Do not speak harsh words;lg==
He who speaks thus must fear retribution.lg==
Evil being done, disaster will follow,lg==
And knives and rods will come upon your body (5).lg==
Be kind in uttering words,lg==
Like knocking at a gong [gently].lg==
When you dispute no more,lg==
You will transcend existence easily (6).lg==
He who strikes the good ones with sticks,lg==
And vilifies those who are innocent;lg==
Will be retributed ten-fold with misfortune.lg==
Which will befall him promptly and inevitably (7).lg==
[Firstly], severe pain while living (8),lg==
[Secondly], physical injury;lg==
[Thirdly], spontaneous illness;lg==
[Fourthly], mental disorder (9);lg==
[Fifthly], false accusation from others;lg==
[Sixthly], trouble from the magistrate;lg==
[Seventhly], destruction of assets;lg==
[Eighthly], separation from relative (10);lg==
[Ninethly] His houses, and everything thereinlg==
Being burnt away by fire;lg==
[Tenthly] Falling into hell at death.lg==
Such are the ten [misfortune] (11).lg==
Though one might go naked or shave one's head,lg==
Or for life put on straw-clothes,lg==
Or bathe oneself [in sacred rivers] [or] squat on rocks,lg==
What use are these for [overcoming] one's doubts (12)?lg==
He who neither strikes, kills nor burns,lg==
Nor seeks to be a winner;lg==
Who loves (13) all living beings,lg==
Will meet with no enmity (14).lg==
If there be a person in the world,lg==
Who knows to be shameful;lg==
He is one being induced to progress, (such a person can be said to tempted to progress CH)lg==
Like a thorough bred being whipped (15).lg==
Like a fine horse when whipped,lg==
Advances far on the path.lg==
Even so a man endowed with fair virtue,lg==
Mental concentration and vigour;lg==
Commits to the Path (16) and accomplishes wisdom (17),lg==
Hereby elimiting all sufferings (18).lg==
He who [though] well adorned practises the dharma (19), (He who is strict with himself so as to cultivate the Law CH)lg==
Who restrains himself (20) and upholds the pure life,lg==
Laying aside the cudgel towards all creatures,lg==
Is said to be a cultivator (21).lg==
He who is harmless towards all creatures,lg==
Will never in his life be harmed.lg==
If he is always kind towards all,lg==
Who is there to be his enemy(22)?lg==

div.head:
老耗品《法句經》第十九十有四章
The chapter on 'Old Age'

p.seg: What's there to rejoice, what's there to laugh?lg==
Life is always in a blaze!lg==
Deeply concealed in Darkness,lg==
It's better to seek light (1). (to rejoice or to laugh is like not looking for a lamp/the lamp of the buddhist truth CH)lg==
Look at this physical bodylg==
Which [the fool] clings (2) to as comfort.lg==
It's full of [false] thinking and causes sickness,lg==
How does [the fool] know its unreality (3)?lg==
When one gets old, the body becomes weak,lg==
Sickness befalls and lustre is lost;lg==
The skin slackens, and muscles contract.lg==
One is fast approaching death (4).lg==
When the body dies, consciousness departs,lg==
Like a driver abandoning a vehicle;lg==
The flesh diappears, the bones scatterlg==
What is there in the body to rely on (5)?lg==
The body is like a city,lg==
Framed with bones and plastered with flesh.lg==
From birth till old age and death,lg==
It stores nothing but hatred and conceit (6).lg==
When one gets old, the body changes,lg==
Just like an old vehicle.lg==
The Dharma can end sufferinglg==
-practise it with deligence (7).lg==
If a man has heard no [wise teaching]lg==
He will grow old to be a bull:lg==
With only well developed flesh, (only grow so that the flesh becomes fat>abundant CH)lg==
But no wisdom (8).lg==
The cycle of birth and death is boring;lg==
The coming and going is troublesome.lg==
When one's thoughts are attached to the body,lg==
Endless suffering will follow (9).lg==
As the wise perceives suffering,lg==
He accordingly abandons the body;lg==
His thoughts are ceased and conditioning (10) cut off;lg==
And lust being ended, there is no more birth (11).lg==
He who neither practises the Brahma-like faring,lg==
Nor has acquired any wealth;lg==
At old age, is like a white heronlg==
Watching an empty pond (12).lg==
If one neither observes the preceptslg==
Nor accumulates wealth;lg==
When old and weak and panting,lg==
What's the use of reminiscing the past (13)?lg==
At old age, one is like the autumn's leaves;lg==
One moves (14) in filth, and wears tattered clothes (15).lg==
Life is rapidly escaping from this birth;lg==
There is no (17) use to regret (18).lg==
Life is running out as days and nights pass.lg==
Strive hard when there is still time.lg==
What pertains to the world is truly impermanent,lg==
Don't be deluded and fall into darkness (19).lg==
Learn to kindle the mind lamp,lg==
And train yourself to gain wisdom.lg==
Move away from taints, don't fet stained;lg==
Holding the [mind] candle, watch the stages of progress (20).lg==

div.head:
愛身品《法句經》第二十十有三章
The aim of this chapter on 'Self-Concern'lg==

p.seg: He who has love for himself (2)lg==
should cautiously protect what is being guarded (3),lg==
He should aspire for the release from cravinglg==
And, forgoing sleep, to be rectified (4).lg==
Oneself comes (5) first,lg==
One should (train) hard oneself;lg==
When benefit is derived, then instruct others.lg==
The wise is thus not vexed (7).lg==
First learn to rectify oneself,lg==
Then only rectify others.lg==
Train yourself to enter wisdom,lg==
And you will surely move upwards (8).lg==
If one cannot benefit oneself,lg==
How can one benefit others?lg==
When one's mind is tamed, and body rectified,lg==
What aim is there that cannot be achieved (9).lg==
What has been done by oneself before,lg==
One will experience its effect later.lg==
Having done evil, one [suffers] through oneself,lg==
Like a diamond boring through a gem (10).lg==
If one does not observe the precepts,lg==
[Craving] will spread like a rattan creeper.lg==
One's desires being unrestrained,lg==
Evil actions will increase day by day (11).lg==
Evil actions endanger oneself;lg==
They are easy for the fool.lg==
Good actions are one's best security;lg==
They are difficult for the fool (12).lg==
Those who accord with the True Men's teaching,lg==
And live (13) in accordance with Truth,lg==
The fool envies them,lg==
And views them as evil (14).lg==
Evil actions yield bad [results],lg==
Like the sowing of bitter seeds.lg==
Having done evil, one suffers oneself;lg==
Having done good, one experiences happiness oneself.lg==
And (15) each [result] must ripen [accordingly]lg==
-It cannot be [experienced] on each other's behalf.lg==
[Like-wise], good actions yield good [results],lg==
Like the sowing of sweet seeds (16).lg==
One should benefit oneself as well as others,lg==
And there will be benefit without much effort (17).lg==
If one desires to know how to benefit oneself,lg==
[Here it is]: Precepts and knowledge (18) are the best (19).lg==
One who has love for himself,lg==
And wishes to be born in heavens,lg==
Should, with respect and delight, listen to the Dharmalg==
And remember the Buddha's Teachings (20).lg==
One must think carefully before any undertaking,lg==
So that one's effort would not be spoilt.lg==
Thus one's thinking becomes more and more trained,lg==
And one does not miss the time for any undertaking (21).lg==
One who has his undertaking well prepared,lg==
Can reach the goal and achieve profit.lg==
A true understanding would be put into practice,lg==
And one will thereby achieve one's aim (22).lg==

div.head:
世俗品《法句經》第二十一十有四章
The chapter on 'The world'lg==

p.seg: As a cart travelling on the road,lg==
Which, leaving the level, broad road,lg==
Turns onto a small side road and is crashedlg==
-There is the sorrow of the breaking of the axles (1).lg==
Likewise, leaving the Dharmalg==
To follow and develop that opposed to Dharma,lg==
The fool keeps his way until deathlg==
-And there is also the sorrow of being broken (2).lg==
Fare in accordance with Dharma,lg==
Do not accord with evil deed;lg==
The dharma-farer (3) sleeps well,lg==
And there is no sorrow in every existence (4).lg==
All things are like foam,lg==
The mind is like a wild horse;lg==
Living in a world like a mirage,lg==
How can one delight in it (5)?lg==
If one can break away from this,lg==
Cutting the tree its roots,lg==
And persisting thus day and night,lg==
One will surely achieve concentration (6).lg==
Some give in accordance with faith,lg==
Like people who are happy;lg==
Others, from a perturbed mind,lg==
Offer food to the [monk-] communitylg==
-Such people, day and nightlg==
Achieve no mental concentration (7).lg==
The worldlings have no eyes;lg==
They see not the truth of the Way.lg==
Those with even a little clarity of vision,lg==
Should nurture good thoughts (8).lg==
Like goose heading its group,lg==
To fly high in voidance of the net;lg==
The wise one leads the world,lg==
To get freed from the evil ones (9).lg==
All worldlings must die,lg==
There is no security in the three spheres.lg==
Though the gods may enjoy themselves,lg==
They too die when their merit is exhausted (10).lg==
Observe the worldlings:lg==
No birth does not come to an end.lg==
If one wishes to escape the cycle of rebirth,lg==
One should practise the true Path (11).lg==
Delusion covers up the whole world;lg==
Greed causes the loss of sight.lg==
False [views] (12) and doubt lead to rejecting Truth (13).lg==
-The afflicted fools accord with these (14).lg==
He who has transgressed one dharma,lg==
Namely, the liar,lg==
Will not escape future existence,lg==
And there's is no evil that he will not further (15) do (16).lg==
Though one may pile up treasure,lg==
To as high as the heavens,lg==
Thus filling up the whole world;lg==
It's better to gain insight into th Path (17).lg==
What is not good appears to be good,lg==
Lust appears to be not lust;lg==
Suffering is taken for happinesslg==
-the insane is devoted to (18) [these false views] (19).lg==

div.head: 《法句經》序
述佛品《法句經》第二十二二十有一章

p.seg: The chapter 'On The Buddha's virtues"
explains [the Buddha's] holy virtues
which are always beneficial for salvation;
they are made clear so that they may serve as guiding principles for the world.
Having (1) made the conquest he is not subject to evil (2),lg==
He is completely victorious over the world;lg==
Saintly wise, and of boundless sphere,lg==
[The Buddha] initiates the ignorant into the Path (3).lg==
Disentangled from [craving's] net end unimpeded;lg==
Lust exhausted, with nothing to amass;lg==
The Buddha's mind is profound, without a limit.lg==
He leads those not on the Path to embark on it (4).lg==
Steadfastly established in one-mindedness,lg==
Left home, in quiescence day and night,lg==
Root cut off, with no lustful thoughtslg==
-[Such are] the awakened ones (5), the clearly mindful (6).lg==
He has seen the Thruth, and is pure, undefiled,lg==
Having crossed the sea of the five pathwayslg==
-The Buddha- arises, illuminating the world,lg==
In order to remove sufferings (7).lg==
Difficult it it is to be born as a human.lg==
Difficult too the obtaining of longivity for mortals.lg==
Difficult is the arising of Buddhas in the world.lg==
Difficult it is to hear the Buddha-dharma (8).lg==
I had no one for a master (9),lg==
Alone, nor had I any companion.lg==
Accumulating one (10) practice I have become a Buddha.lg==
By myself (11) I have mastered the Noble Path (12).lg==
A boatman can cross over water;lg==
Vigour serves as the bridge.lg==
Men are bound by their casted;lg==
He who can cross over is a hero (13).lg==
Those having destroyed evil and crossed over are the Buddhas.lg==
Those on the land are the brahmins.lg==
Those who remove famine are the Dharma-trainees.lg==
Those who cut off the castle lineage are the disciples (14).lg==
Of mental devotion, endurance is foremost.lg==
'Nirvana is supreme' say the Buddhas.lg==
He who has left home (15) to be a sramanalg==
Does no harm to others (16).lg==
Do not harass by speech or harm;lg==
Restrain fully in accordance with the precepts;lg==
Be moderate in food and give up bodily greed;lg==
Maintain your practice in a secluded abode;lg==
Apply your mind to the gaining of wisdom (17).lg==
-This is practising the Buddhas' teaching.lg==
Not to do evil,lg==
To cultivate all good,lg==
To purify one's own mind,lg==
-This is the Teaching of the Buddhas (19).lg==
[I,] (20) the Buddha am the Exalted One;lg==
[I] have eradicated the cankers and have no lust;lg==
[I] am the hero amongst the Sakyans;lg==
The whole lot [of gods and men] (21) accords with [my] mind (22).lg==
Happy indeed is the result of merit;lg==
Whereby all wishes are fulfilled.lg==
[One with merit] promptly moves to quiescencelg==
And arrives by himself at Nirvana (23).lg==
Many go for refugelg==
To spirits in hills, rivers and trees,lg==
And to images in shrines;lg==
Offering sacrifices and praying for blessings (24).lg==
Refuges like theselg==
Are neither safe nor supreme.lg==
They cannot comelg==
To deliver us from all unsatisfactoriness (25).lg==
If one goes for refugelg==
To the Buddha, Dharma and Sangha;lg==
The virtous Four Truths;lg==
One will definitely see [with] Right Knowledge (26):lg==
[Namely], That samsara is extremely unsatisfactory;lg==
That from [seeing] the Truths one crosses over (27).lg==
That the Eight-fold Path which transcends existence,lg==
Eradicates all unsatisfactoriness (28).lg==
Refuge in these Three Treasured Ones,lg==
Is most safe, is supreme;lg==
Only if one has these [refuges]lg==
Can one transcend all unsatisfactoriness (29).lg==
If a man [accord with] the middle and the proper,lg==
And sets his mind on the Way, without miserliness;lg==
Propitious indeed such a man is,lg==
Who goes for refuge in the Buddha (30).lg==
A man of wisdom is hard to encounter,lg==
And he is not to be found everywhere;lg==
Where such a man is born,lg==
The kinsmen are blessed (31).lg==
Happy is the arising of Buddhas.lg==
Happy is the preaching of the Doctrine.lg==
Happy is the unity of the Sangha;lg==
Unity brings constant peace (32).lg==

div.head:
安寧品《法句經》第二十三十有四章
安寧品者， The chapter on 'Happiness' (1)

p.seg: We (20) already live in happiness,lg==
Hating not amidst the hateful.lg==
While others harbour hatred,lg==
We course without hating (3).lg==
We already live in happiness,lg==
Not falling sick amidst the sick.lg==
While others fall sick,lg==
We course without sickness (4).lg==
We already live in happiness,lg==
Worrying not amidst the worried.lg==
While others have worries,lg==
We course without worrying (5).lg==
We already live in happiness,lg==
Pure, desiring naught (6).lg==
We feed on joy,lg==
Even as the Radiant Devas (7).lg==
We already live in happinesslg==
Living a simple life, contendted.lg==
The fir of Mithila kingdom (8)lg==
-How can it burn us (9)?lg==
Victory begets hatred;lg==
The defeated feels inferior.lg==
Renouncing thoughts of victory and defeat,lg==
One is happy, without combatting (10).lg==
There is no heat like lust,lg==
There is no poison like anger;lg==
There is no misery like the body;lg==
There is no happiness like the quiescence [of Nirvana] (11).lg==
Without being happy with small happiness,lg==
Small eloquence, small intelligence;lg==
He who sets is mind on the big ones,lg==
Will achieve big happiness (12).lg==
I am the World Honoured Onelg==
Forever released, sorrowless.lg==
I have perfectly transcended the triple existence;lg==
And alone, defeated the evil ones (13).lg==
Happiness is seeing the holy ones.lg==
Happiness is the association [with them].lg==
Being able to part with foolslg==
Is good and uniquely happy (14).lg==
Happiness is the keeping to the Right Path.lg==
Happiness is the skillful (15). preaching of Dharma.lg==
By not disputing with the world,lg==
And endowed with precepts, one is always happy (16).lg==
Happiness is living with the virtous,lg==
Like [that of] meeting with kinsfolk.lg==
He who draws near to the virtous and wiselg==
will hear much and get far away (17).lg==
Few are those who live long,lg==
And many are those who leave the world.lg==
In one's training one should seze the meanslg==
Which gives happiness til old age (18).lg==
For those wishing for the ambrosia,lg==
The cessation Truth- the removal of craving- is bliss.lg==
Those wishing to transcend the suffering of samsara;lg==
Should take the taste of ambrosia (19).lg==

div.head:
好喜品《法句經》第二十四十有二章
The chapter on affection

p.seg: What contravenes the spiritual life (1) one accords with it;lg==
What accords with the spiritual life one contravenes it,lg==
Leaving the real good one grasps at the pleasantlg==
-Such is according with craving (2).lg==
Do not seek to be with the belovedlg==
Nor should one have enbeloved.lg==
The meeting with the beloved is painful;lg==
Meeting with the unbeloved is also painful (3).lg==
Therefore create not any endearmentlg==
Affection and hatred originate from evil.lg==
For those who are freed from bonds,lg==
There is neither affection nor hatred (4).lg==
Endearment begets sorrowlg==
Endearment begets fearlg==
For him free from endearmentlg==
Whence sorrow, whence fear? (5)lg==
Craving begets sorrowlg==
Craving begets fearlg==
For him liberated, without craving;lg==
Whence sorrow whence fear? (7)lg==
Craving begets sorrowlg==
Craving begets fearlg==
For him liberated, without without craving;lg==
Whence sorrow whence fear? (7)lg==
He who desires the Dharma, endowed with virtue,lg==
He who is thruthful and shameful,lg==
Who goads himself to be near the Way (8),lg==
Him do people hold dear. (7)lg==
He who externalizes not his desire state,lg==
Who speaks having first rectified his thoughts,lg==
Whose mind is free from lust'lg==
Will stop the stream and cross over (10).lg==
As one who has gone on a long journey,lg==
And returns safe from afar;lg==
His kinsfolk are well and happy,lg==
Rejoicing to see him return (11).lg==
Likewise, he who delights to in merit-making,lg==
Having gone from here to therelg==
Will receive the blessing of his meritlg==
Just as kinsmen's rejoicing in his return (12).lg==
Rise up and follow the holy teachings,lg==
Restrain from what is unskilful.lg==
When you meet one close to the Way, devote to him;lg==
Do not get close away from the Way (13).lg==
Those near the way and those not,lg==
Will go (14) to different places:lg==
Those near Way will axcend to heaven;lg==
Those not near will fall into hell (15).lg==

div.head:
忿怒品《法句經》第二十五二十有六章
The purpose of the chapter on "Anger"

p.seg: He who is angry sees not the Dharma;lg==
He who is angry knows not the Way (1).lg==
He who can remove anger,lg==
Merit and joy always follow him (2).lg==
He who is lustful sees not the Dharma;lg==
The same for he whose mind is delusion,lg==
He who removes lust and delusion,lg==
His merit stands foremost (3).lg==
He who can refrain from anger,lg==
Like halting a running chariot;lg==
Is indeed a fine charioteer,lg==
Who leaves darkness to enter brightness (4).lg==
Forbearance excels anger (5);lg==
Good excels evil;lg==
The winner (6) is one who gives;lg==
Truthfulness excels deceit (7).lg==
Do not cheat, do not get angry,lg==
Do not seek much in your mind,lg==
He who [can do] these three,lg==
Ascends to heaven at death (8).lg==
Those who are ever restrained in body,lg==
Who are kind and do not kill;lg==
Go to the celestial abodeslg==
And having reached there become sorrowless (9).lg==
Those whose mind is always awake.lg==
Who diligently practice day and night (10);lg==
With their mind determined (11) to end corruptions (12).lg==
They will attain Nirvana.lg==
People blame one another,lg==
From time of old till now.lg==
They blame him of old till now.lg==
They blame him who is reluctant to speak (14),lg==
And him who speaks in moderation;lg==
In the world none is not blamed (15).lg==
One with a craving mind is unlike a noble one,lg==
Not being able to keep to the Middle.lg==
He either blames altogether or praises altogether;lg==
All in order to promote (16) hos own name (17).lg==
He who is praised by the wise,lg==
Is to be regarded as virtous.lg==
Such a man endowed with wisdom and preceptslg==
Is beyond any blame whatsoever (18).lg==
He who is pure as an arahat;lg==
Do not vilify him.lg==
He is praised by gods (19),lg==
As by Brahma and Sakya (20).lg==
Always guard and be cautious of your body,lg==
So as to be restrained from anger (21).lg==
Forsaking evil bodily acts,lg==
Advance in the practice of virtous (22).lg==
Always guard and be cautious of your speechlg==
So as to be restrained from anger (21).lg==
Forsaking evil bodily acts,lg==
Advance in the practice of virtues (22).lg==
Always guard and be cautious of your mind,lg==
So as to be restrained from anger.lg==
Forsaking evil thoughts in the mind,lg==
Meditate and be mindful of the Way (24).lg==
He who is restrained in body and speechlg==
And who controls his mind;lg==
Giving up anger and practising the Way,lg==
Is the strongest in forbearance (25).lg==
Give up anger, renounce conceitlg==
And avoid all lustful cravings (26).lg==
Not clinging to the psycho-physical existence,lg==
And being unattached, one will end suffering (27).lg==
He who removes anger the moment it arises;lg==
He who restrains from lust as it occurs;lg==
He who is heroic in renouncing ignorance;lg==
All these people will find happiness (28).lg==
He who cuts off anger sleeps well,lg==
Hatred ceasing, there is no (29) sorrow.lg==
Anger is the root of all poisons.lg==
A brahmin with a soft mindlg==
And good words will gain fame;lg==
[Anger] removed, there is no worry (30).lg==
He who, together with other like-minded,lg==
Collaborates in evil doing;lg==
Company being parted, is left with anger,lg==
With which fire he torments himself (31).lg==
He who knows no moral fear or shame,lg==
Who observes no precepts and is angry;lg==
Is dragged on by angerlg==
And never gets tired of the toil of existence (32).lg==
The strong goes near [and clash with] the warriors.lg==
Those without strength go near the weak.lg==
[But] endurance is indeed best;lg==
One should always endure the weak (34).lg==
We as much as others,lg==
Have great fear regarding three (35).lg==
If we perceive the [mis-] deeds of otherslg==
We should destroy [the fault] (36) within ourselves (37).lg==
We as much as others,lg==
Have great fear regarding three (35).lg==
If we perceive the [mis-] deeds of otherslg==
We should destroy [the fault] (36) within ourselves (37).lg==
Do things from the view-points of both:lg==
Ourselves as much as others (38).lg==
If we perceive the [mis-] deeds of otherslg==
We should destroy [the faults] within ourselves (39).lg==
The very wise ones excel the fools (40),lg==
Who utter abuse and evil words.lg==
He who wishes to win always,lg==
Should remain silent to (abusive) wors (41).lg==
The doers of evillg==
Get retribution of anger for their anger,lg==
Those who reciprocate not anger with anger,lg==
Win over those defeated in clashes (42).lg==

div.head:
塵垢品《法句經》第二十六十有九章
-

p.seg: He who while living has done no good,lg==
At death will fall into the evil destinies.lg==
Swiftly he will go with no [rest] in betweenlg==
And on arriving, he will find no provisions (1).lg==
You should seek wisdomlg==
To light up the mind lamp (2).lg==
Remove taints, don't be defiled;lg==
And you will be rid of the unsatisfactory body (3).lg==
The wise man, gradually,lg==
Slowly and progressively,lg==
Cleanses his mind of stains;lg==
Like a smith refining gold (4).lg==
Evil, arisen in a man's mindlg==
Corrodes his own body,lg==
Even as rust from an ironlg==
Eats away itself (5).lg==
Non-recitation is the taint of wordslg==
Nonexertion is the taint of the homelg==
Non-adornment is the taint of beautylg==
Heedlessness is the taint of work (6).lg==
Avarice is the taint of givinglg==
Unskillfulness is the taint of action,lg==
Both in this life and in the next,lg==
Evil dharmas always constitute taints (7).lg==
The taint of all taintslg==
Is ignorance, the worst.lg==
Train to give up evil,lg==
O bhiksus! and be taintless (8).lg==
An easy life is one without shame,lg==
Like a crow with a long beaklg==
Which brazenly bears dishonour.lg==
-Such is a life of defilement (9).lg==
A shameful person, though life be hard,lg==
Takes righteously, [remaining] cleanly [of life].lg==
He shuns dishonour and recklessness.lg==
Such is a life of purity (10).lg==
A fool is one indulging in killing,lg==
In speaking untruth,lg==
In taking what is not given,lg==
In trespassing on other's wives (11).lg==
In conscious moral transgressionslg==
In getting addicted to intoxication drinkslg==
Such a man, in every lifelg==
Digs up his own rood (12).lg==
Understand thus, O manlg==
Do not contemplate on evil;lg==
A fool who draws near to wickednesslg==
Will for long get himself burnt (13).lg==
People give either out of faithlg==
Or in order to get fame.lg==
If one covets (14) others' worthless ornaments,lg==
One will not attain pure concentration (16).lg==
If one completely removes covetousness,lg==
Cutting off the [craving] mind by the root,lg==
And remains one-minded day and night,lg==
One is sure to attain mental concentration.lg==
Sensual attachment (17) constitutes a taint;lg==
From defilement, there is the corruption (18) of taintslg==
Not getting defiled, nor coursing [in sensual attachment]lg==
One is sure to attain mental concentration (16).lg==
Seeing others corroding themselves,lg==
One should always reflect within:lg==
Corruption in practice is self-humiliation;lg==
Corruptions having ended, there is no taint (20).lg==
There is no fire hotter than lust.lg==
There is no speed greater than anger.lg==
There is no net denser than delusion.lg==
The craving stream is more rapid than a river (21).lg==
There is no track in the skylg==
There is no outside thought for a sramanalg==
Men all delight in evil (22)lg==
Only the Buddha is pure, without defilement (23).lg==
There is no track in the sky.lg==
There are no outside thoughts for a sramana.lg==
In the world nothing has permanence.lg==
For the Buddha, there is naught of the self (24).lg==

div.head:
奉持品《法句經》第二十七十有七章
The chapter on the 'Spiritually Committed'

p.seg: He who is committed to the spiritual path (2)lg==
Does not compete for profits.lg==
Regarding the profitable and the unprofitable,lg==
He is desireless and undeluded (3).lg==
He who is ever kind and ready to learn,lg==
Who courses with a righteous mindlg==
Embracing the precious [Dharma] at heart, wise;lg==
Is indeed one cultivating the path (4).lg==
One becomes a wise onelg==
Not necessarily by arguing much.lg==
He who is secure and fearlesslg==
And guards his goodness, is indeed wise (5).lg==
One is an upholder of the Dharmalg==
Not simply by speaking much.lg==
He who, though not having heard muchlg==
Puts the Dharma into practice himselflg==
And who forgets not the Teaching (6)lg==
May be called a Dharma upholder (7).lg==
One becomes an elderlg==
Not simply by being old,lg==
With ripened body and grey hairs.lg==
Such a person [can] be just a fool (8).lg==
He who in whom are thruth, Dharma,lg==
Restraint and kindness;lg==
Who is wise (9) and pure,lg==
Is indeed and Elder (10).lg==
One becomes gracefull (11)lg==
Not having flower-like complexion (12)lg==
While being miserly, jealus and deceitful,lg==
And acting contrary to is words (13).lg==
He who can renounce evillg==
Having cut it off by its root,lg==
Who is wise and hatred-freelg==
Is said to be graceful (14).lg==
One becomes a sramanalg==
Not merely by shaving one's headlg==
While still telling lies and coveting,lg==
Full of desires like the ordinary people (15).lg==
He who can stop doing evillg==
Who generously propagates the Teachinglg==
Who stills his mind and thoughtslg==
Is indeed a sramana (16).lg==
One becomes a bhiksulg==
Not merely by begging at timeslg==
While having evil acts and sexual indulgencelg==
This is bhiksu by name only (17).lg==
He who abandoning both merit and demeritlg==
Leads the pure spiritual lifelg==
Who is wise and banishes evil,lg==
Is indeed a bhiksu (18).lg==
One becomes a sagelg==
Not by [mere] silence,lg==
Having impure intentions withinlg==
And pretending externally (19).lg==
One is said to spiritually advanced (21)lg==
Not [simply] by saving one lifelg==
He who strives for universal salvation,lg==
Harmless, is indeed spiritually advanced (22).lg==
Do not boast of your observances,lg==
[Or that] "My actions are mostly truthful" (23).lg==
[Or that] "I have attained mental concentrationlg==
By resorting to solitude."lg==
Be determined to seek happiness;lg==
Don't learn from the ordinary worldlings.lg==
So long as your corruptions are not extinctlg==
You will not be liberated (25).lg==

div.head:
道行品《法句經》第二十八二十有八章
The purpose of this chapter on 'The Path'

p.seg: The best of paths is the eight-fold right [path]lg==
Four-Truths are the track of Dharma (1)lg==
The best of practices is the giving up of lust.lg==
The giving of lamps (2) ensures the obtaining of eyes (3)lg==
This is the Path, there is no more fear; (4).lg==
When views are purified, ome will transcend existence,lg==
This [Path can crush Mara's army;lg==
Walk on with effort to end suffering (5)lg==
I have already opened up the Right Path,lg==
To fully display the unique splendour.lg==
Having heard it you must train yourself;lg==
Treading it leads to release from the evil bonds (6)lg==
Phenomenal existence (7) is permanent and unsatisfactory;lg==
He who sees this is wise a wise one.lg==
One wishing to be freed from unsatisfactoriness,lg==
Has only tread the Path with diligence (9)lg==
Phenomminal existence (7) is impermanet and usatisfactory;lg==
He who sees this is a wise one.lg==
One wishing to be freed from unsatisfactoriness,lg==
Has only to tread the Path with diligence (9)lg==
One should get up when it's time (10) to do solg==
Don't be like the fools drowned in deep water,lg==
Who assemble with the lazy (11) and indiffernet, (12)lg==
And feel too tired to advance on the Path (13)lg==
Mindfulness of that to be mindful of is right,lg==
Mindfulness of that not to be mindful of is wrong.lg==
Be wise and do't give rise to wrong [thoughts]lg==
Thoughts being rectified, the Goal will be reached (14)lg==
Cautious in speech and watchful of the mind,lg==
And doing no bodily act which is unskillfullg==
-He who thus removes the threefold [unskillful] deeds,lg==
The Buddha declares, has achieved the Goal (15)lg==
If the tree is cut without being uprooted;lg==
The root still remaining, it will grow again.lg==
Remove the root, then there will be no tree,lg==
And the bhiksu will gain Nirvana (16)lg==
So long as one cannot cut down the trees;lg==
There being mutual attachment between relations, (17)lg==
One binds oneself with the greedy mindlg==
Like a calf after [the mother's] milk (18)lg==
He who can cut off the root of craving (10)lg==
[The root of] the endless cycle of rebirths, (20)lg==
Is said to near the Way (21)lg==
And will soon attain Nirvana (22)lg==
Lust results in ageing;lg==
Hatred in sickness;lg==
Delusion results in death;lg==
The three removed, one will reach the Goal. (23)lg==
Released at the beginning, released at the end,lg==
Released in the middle-one crosses to the other [shore].lg==
All thoughts having been extinguished,lg==
There will be no more old-age and death (24)lg==
To one entangled with wife and sons,lg==
Not contemplating on the ill [natur of] dharmas,lg==
Death will come abruptly,lg==
Like the rapid flow of flood water (25)lg==
Neither father nor son can save,lg==
What hope then from other kinsmen?lg==
To lean for support from kinsmen at life's end,lg==
Is like a blind relying on a lamp (26).lg==
The wise who understands this meaning,lg==
Should put into practice the sutra and vinaya (27)lg==
Practising diligently to transcend the world,lg==
And unsatisfactoriness will be completely removed. (28)lg==
Get far away from the deep-waterlg==
Like the wind banishing the cloudslg==
All conceptions having ceased;lg==
It is said to be the vision of wisdom (29)lg==
Wisdom is the world's foremost;lg==
[With it] one contentedly delights in the unconditioned,lg==
And knows (30) the true teachings,lg==
Bringing an end to birth and death (31)lg==
He who knows the conditioning to be unsatisfactorylg==
-This is seeing with wisdom-lg==
Becomes disgusted with worldly unsatisfactoriness;lg==
And from this Path [unsatisfactoriness] is removed (33)lg==
He who knows the conditioning to be unsatisfactorylg==
-This is seeing with wisdom-lg==
Becomes disgusted with worldly unsatisfactoriness;lg==
And from this Path [unsatisfactoriness] is removed (33)lg==
He who knows the conditioning to be unsatisfactorylg==
-This is seeing with wisdom-lg==
Becomes disgusted with worldly unsatisfactorness;lg==
And from this Path [unsatisfactoriness] is removed. (34)lg==
I expounded to you the Dharma,lg==
Having [myself once] been shot with the arrows of craving (35)lg==
You should endeavour yourselflg==
And accept the Tathagata's word (36)lg==
I am one who have completely destroeyed [the defilement]lg==
And ended the coming and going - birth and death.lg==
It is for the liberation of not [just] one single being,lg==
What has been expounded, the Path-eye. (37)lg==
Just as the rivers flow into the sea,lg==
And the water in turn flows on to quickly fill up (38).lg==
Therefore is [the Path] taught to the wise,lg==
By which they can be led to taking the amrata. (39)lg==
The hitherto unheard of dharma-wheellg==
[The Buddha] turned, out of compassion for beings.lg==
Thoses who devote themselves to Himlg==
Salute Him, and transend the triple existence. (40)lg==
Three thoughts (41) are to be cultivated; being skillfullg==
Three also are to be removed; (42) being unskillful.lg==
From thoughts, there arises actions;lg==
These ceased, it is called true abandonment (43)lg==
Three meditations can transform thoughts (44).lg==
Give up attachment and practise the immeasureable.lg==
Attaining these three, three dens are removed. (45)lg==
To be freed from the fetters, be mindful (46)lg==
He who knows to restrain from evil with the preceps,lg==
Contemplative and wise, delighting in mindfulness,lg==
Has understood the arising and perishing of the world,lg==
His thoughts having ceased, he is liberated from all. (47)lg==

div.head:
廣衍品《法句經》第二十九十有四章
The chapter on 'Spreading Extensively'

p.seg: Though the happiness in giving may be smalllg==
Its retribution is very great.lg==
The wise one, from a small giving,lg==
Sees in retribution, a great blessing (2).lg==
He who be causing hardship to otherslg==
Seeks to gain blessinglg==
Misfortune will befall him,lg==
Having himself befriended enemies widely (3).lg==
For one has done various things,lg==
Including the improper ones,lg==
And is sporty and heedless;lg==
His corruptions increase day by day (4).lg==
He who vigorously practises meditation,lg==
Who pursues the proper and gives up the improper,lg==
Who cultivates himself and is mindful,lg==
Is indeed one endowed with the right practice (5).lg==
For one who being inintelligent,lg==
Is moreover keen to learn;lg==
[His knowledge] will gradually expand,lg==
like ghee when thrown into water (6).lg==
For one being unintelligent,lg==
Is moreover not keen to learn;lg==
His knowledge will contract and get less,lg==
Like curd when thrown into water (7).lg==
The names of the spiritual cultivators shine forthlg==
Like snow on high mountains.lg==
Those with no spirituality remain obscurelg==
Like arrows shot at night (10).lg==
The disciples of the Buddha,lg==
Are ever awake and self-aware.lg==
Day and night they recollect the Buddha,lg==
Reflect on the Dharma, and are mindful of the Sangha (11)lg==
The disciples of the Buddhalg==
Are ever (12) awake and self-aware.lg==
Day and night they think of meditating,lg==
And delight in contemplation and one-mindedness (13).lg==
One should maintain mindfulnesslg==
And know the amount (14) to eatlg==
One's sensual craving (15) is then reducedlg==
And digestion being regulated, one lives long (16).lg==
Hard it is to undergo training and give up evil.lg==
Har too it is to live the household life.lg==
Hard [also] is living and sharing with others.lg==
Of all hardships, existence is the greatest (17).lg==
Hard it is for a bhiksu to beg [for alms]lg==
How then can you not spur yourself on?lg==
With vigour, you'll obtain easelg==
And hereafter (18) you'll not covet other's [things] (19).lg==
He who has faith (20) will be endowed with virtue;lg==
From virtue, he will attain wealth;lg==
From the same will he obtain a happy partner;lg==
Wherever he goes, he recieves offerings (21).lg==
He who sits alone, rests in one place (22),lg==
Walks alone, unindolent,lg==
And keeping to solitude rectifies the self;lg==
Will delight in forest dwelling (23).lg==

div.head:
地獄品《法句經》第三十十有六章
The chapter on 'The Hells'

p.seg: The liar approaches hell,lg==
[Also] he who having done something says he hasn't.lg==
Both these offenders hereafter will suffer alike,lg==
Having dragged themselves there with such actions (1).lg==
Those who donning the robes;lg==
commit evil, and are unrestrained;lg==
Such base evil doers,lg==
At death will fall into hells (2).lg==
If one, being immoral, accepts offerings,lg==
Would he not be harming himself?lg==
At death he will swallow red-hot iron balls,lg==
And be burnt by flaring charcoals (3).lg==
Four things beset the heedless manlg==
Who is fond of committing adultery;lg==
[First] bad sleep, [second] demerit,lg==
Third ill-repute, and fourth sensual indulgence (4).lg==
There being demerit, he will have bad rebirth.lg==
The fearful [man] and fearful (5) [woman] enjoy but little.lg==
The king imposes heavy punishment on them.lg==
And at death they go to hell (6).lg==
Just as in the uprooting of wild grasses (7);lg==
If not grabbed properly, they cut the hamd.lg==
In ethical training, if there be faults,lg==
One is picked for hell one's own making (8).lg==
In the ordinary man's faring, if there be slackness,lg==
It cannot lead to the removal of hardship.lg==
In the spiritual faring, if there be faults,lg==
It will never yield great blessing (10).lg==
Always do what you ought to do,lg==
Persevere and make your practice strong.lg==
Seperate yourself from the heretics;lg==
Don't be influenced and tainted (11).lg==
If one does what ought not to be done,lg==
One will later be poisoned with depression.lg==
If one does good one will always be well,lg==
And wherever one is, one has no remorse (12).lg==
He who with regard to an evil deed,lg==
Intends to do or has already done;lg==
Cannot be freed from the ensuing suffering:lg==
Evil retribution nearing, he finds no escape (13).lg==
He who gives false evidence to get bribes;lg==
He who himself having behaved improperly,lg==
Malign the good ones out of hatred;lg==
He who treats the learned unjustly;lg==
-Such people, bound by their evil,lg==
Throw themselves into pits (14).lg==
Like a guarded border city;lg==
Firm within and without.lg==
So guard your own mind,lg==
[Let] no evil thought (15) arises.lg==
Lapses in action beget grief;lg==
And will lead you to hell (16).lg==
Those unashamed of what is shameful,lg==
And ashamed of what is not shameful;lg==
-Such beings, holding false views,lg==
Go to hell at death (17).lg==
Those unafraid of what is not fearful,lg==
And afraid of what is not fearful;lg==
-Such beings, disposed towards false views;lg==
Go to hell at death (19).lg==
Those who approach what should be shunned,lg==
And don't approach what should be approached;lg==
-Such beings, addicted to false views,lg==
Go to hell at death (19).lg==

div.head:
象喻品《法句經》第三十一十有八章
The chapter on 'The Elephant Simile'

p.seg: I, like the elephant in battlelg==
Unafraid of being struck by arrows,lg==
Ever with sincere faithlg==
Transform those without virtues. (1)lg==
Just as a properly trained elephantlg==
Is fit for the king to ride on;lg==
One who is trained is exalted among menlg==
And fit to be believed in. (2)lg==
Even those as properly tamed,lg==
As the through-bred horses of Sinh,lg==
And the best elephants;lg==
Cannot excel a man who has tamed himself (3)lg==
Those [untrained men] (4) cannot golg==
To places where men have not beenlg==
Only those who have subdued themselveslg==
Can go to the place of the subdued (15)lg==
Like an elephant named Dhanapalaka,lg==
Who is ferocious and hard to restrain;lg==
Though chained and not given foodlg==
It still remains wild as a ruttled elephant. (6)lg==
Those immersed in evil actions,lg==
Ever have themselves chained by greed;lg==
Like the elephant which is unsatiable,lg==
And thus repeatedly enter into the womb. (7)lg==
Formerly, the mind has been drifting aimlessly,lg==
And always going where it finds pleasure.lg==
[Now, I] (8)shall give it all up and subdue passions,lg==
Like a mahout subduing an elephant with hooks. (9)lg==
He who delights in the Path and is heedful (10),lg==
Who can constantly protect his mindlg==
Is one who lifts himself out of suffering;lg==
Like an elephant getting out of a trap. (11)lg==
If you get a capable companionlg==
Who would move with you, and is firm in doing good;lg==
You will defeat all the famous (12)lg==
And remain mindful having attained your goal. (14)lg==
If you don't get a capable companionlg==
Who would move with you and is firm in doing good;lg==
Then dissociate from all, [like] a king his lands.lg==
It's better to be alone without doing evil. (16)lg==
It's better to move alone, doing good;lg==
And not befriend the fools.lg==
Be alone and do no evil,lg==
Like a frightened elephant protecting itself (17).lg==
Happiness is to be born with wealth.lg==
Happiness is to have gentle and agreeable friends.lg==
Happiness is having merit at life's end.lg==
Happiness is not committing any evil (18).lg==
Happiness is having a mother in the family.lg==
Happiness too is having a father.lg==
Happiness is the existence of sramanas in the world.lg==
Happiness is the existence of the Way in the world (19).lg==
Happiness is practising virtue till old age.lg==
Good is when one's faith is pure where it should be pure.lg==
Wisdom delights oneself mostlg==
The greatest is not doing evil.lg==
Just as a horse that is properly trained,lg==
Goes according to the tamer's wish;lg==
One endowed with faith, virtue, vigour,lg==
Concentration and examination of dharmas,lg==
Who is established in knowledge and conduct (21),lg==
Who has patience and mental stability,lg==
Will get rid of all suffering,lg==
In accordance with his wish (22).lg==
From this, one will go into concentration (23),lg==
Like a horse having been tamed,lg==
One is freed from anger and the corruptions,lg==
And experiences the bliss of gods. (24)lg==
He who is not heedlesslg==
Will thereby become more wakeful,lg==
Like a nag compared to a fine horse:lg==
He who gives up evil is the better (25).lg==

div.head:
愛欲品《法句經》第三十二三十有二章
The chapter on 'Craving'

p.seg: If one's mind is set onn sexual activities,lg==
One's craving increases, like [a creeper's] branceslg==
Spreading and growing ever more luxuriantly;lg==
And one keeps leaping, like a monkey greedy for fruits (1).lg==
One who for the sake of lust endures sorrow,lg==
Who owing to craving is attached to the world;lg==
His sorrow increases day and night,lg==
Growing and spreading like a vine (2).lg==
Men are deluded because of passionate love;lg==
They are unable to give up passions.lg==
Thus do sorrow and passionate love increase,lg==
Like flowing water filling up a pond (3).lg==
That there are sorrow, grief,lg==
And suffering in the world, of not [just] one kind,lg==
Is due to none but craving.lg==
Craving ceasing, there is no sorrow (4).lg==
One's own mind being at peace, craving (5) is abandoned,lg==
Without craving, where is the world?lg==
Not grieving, nor seeking with defilement.lg==
Nor craving; whence is the world (6)?lg==
Some grieve because at the time of death.lg==
They want many kinsfolks to gather.lg==
Traversing a long journey of sorrow;lg==
They crave and suffer, always falling into distress. (8)lg==
One devoted to the lifelg==
Must not befriend craving.lg==
First cut off the root of craving,lg==
So that it can no more take root.lg==
Don't be like cutting reeds;lg==
lest the craving would arise again (9).lg==
Like tree with deep and firm root,lg==
Though cut down grows yet again;lg==
Craving thoughts not completely removed,lg==
One should expect further suffering (10).lg==
Like a monkey, having left behind the trees,lg==
Returns to the trees having been freed (11);lg==
Even so do people in the world,lg==
Get out of hells only to return to hells. (12)lg==
Greedy thoughts constitute an incessant flow,lg==
Which habitually joins force with conceit.lg==
When one's thoughts are inclined to lust,lg==
One conceals oneself, and sees nothing (13).lg==
All thoughts flow and spread;lg==
The craving-fetter is like a rattan creeper.lg==
The wise alone can discern with discrimination,lg==
And cut off the source of [craving] thoughts.lg==
Nourished by craving,lg==
One's thougths grow and spread.lg==
Craving is deep and fathomless,lg==
Adding strength to old-age and death.lg==
The tributaries (16) produced are incessant,lg==
Feeding on craving alone.lg==
To nourish enemies and multiply graves,lg==
The fools are ever restlessly striving (17).lg==
Though in prison, there are hooks and chains,lg==
Deep, strong, and difficult to escape.lg==
Threfore should it be cut and abandoned;lg==
Not bothered (20) with desire, one is happy (21). SEE NOTESlg==
The wise say that craving is a prison,lg==
Deep, strong, and difficult to escape.lg==
Therefore should it be cut and abandoned;lg==
Not bothered (20) with desire, one is happy.lg==
At the sight of a female, he is tempted,lg==
Not meditating on impermanence.lg==
The fool thinks [of her] as beautifullg==
-How does he know its unreality (22)?lg==
[The fool] envelopes himself with sexual pleasure,lg==
Like the sikworms making their cocoons.lg==
The wise can give it up,lg==
And not being bothered by it, end all sufferings (23).lg==
One whose mind is bent on heedlessness,lg==
Views sexual indulgence as being pure;lg==
His thoughts of passionate love being intensified,lg==
He thus creates a prison (24).lg==
He whose thoughts cease in sexual craving,lg==
Is ever mindful of craving as impure.lg==
Thus does he leave the prison of evil,lg==
And end the problem of old age and death (25).lg==
[The fool] entangles himself with craving's net,lg==
And gets himself covered up by lust's lust.lg==
Being self-indulgent, he is imprisoned;lg==
Like a fish entering a trap (26).lg==
Old-age and death await their chancelg==
Like calves wanting their mother's milk.lg==
Craving abandoned and lust's tracks obliterated,lg==
[The wise] leaves the net disentangled (27).lg==
He who has completed the Way, freed from prison,lg==
Understanding all from one [end] to the other (28);lg==
Has transcended the practice of extremity.lg==
Such a man is a great wise one (29).lg==
Don't be close to those remote from the Dharma,lg==
Don't be stained (30) by lust either.lg==
He who has not cut off the three times,lg==
Will fall again into practice of extremity (31).lg==
If one is awakened to [the true nature of] all dharmas,lg==
One will then not be attached to the dharmas;lg==
Having been freed from all thoughts of lust,lg==
One is said to have mastered the sages' thoughts (32).lg==
Of all gifts, the gift of Buddha's discourses (33) excels.lg==
Of all flavours, the flavour of Truth (34) excels.lg==
Of all bliss, the bliss of Dharma excels.lg==
The exhaustion of lust excels all sufferings (35).lg==
The fool binds himself with greed,lg==
And seeks not to cross over to the other shore.lg==
Owing to greed for wealth and lust (36),lg==
He kills (37) others as well as himself (38).lg==
The craving mind is the field;lg==
Lust, hatred and delusion are the seeds.lg==
Thus giving to those having transcended the world,lg==
One gains immeasurable amount of merit (30).lg==
With a few companions but plenty of goods,lg==
A merchant trembles with fear.lg==
Craving is a robber that kills,lg==
Therefore the wise do not crave (40).lg==
Where the mind agrees, there craving is.lg==
-Why then only the five-fold craving?lg==
The agreement defied and the five-fold craving cut,lg==
One becomes a hero indeed (41).lg==
Where there is no craving, there is no fear;lg==
Where there is contentment there is no sorrow.lg==
When craving is removed and fetters undone,lg==
One is said to be far out from the sea (42).lg==
O craving! I know your fount:lg==
You are born of thoughts in the mind.lg==
The moment I cease thinking of you,lg==
You will exist no more (43).lg==
In cutting trees [of craving], don't stop.lg==
So long as the tree grow, there will be evil,lg==
When each and every tree is cut,lg==
The bhiksu will attain Nirvana (44).lg==
If the trees [of craving] are not cutlg==
- Even if there be a tiny bit of passion remaining,lg==
The mind will get hung up therelg==
Like the calves wanting [milk from] the mother (45).lg==

div.head: 利養品《法句經》第三十三有二十章

沙門品《法句經》第三十四三十有二章
The chapter on 'the Sramana'

p.seg: Upright with regard to eye, ear, nose and mouth,lg==
And ever restrained in body and mind;lg==
A bhiksu who practises thuslg==
Can be free from all suffering (1).lg==
